awd_abstract_narration:
The Finger Lakes Probability Seminar grant will cover the years 2017-2020, according to the following schedule:

April 21-22, 2017 at Syracuse University 
April 20-21, 2018 at University of Rochester 
April 19-20, 2019 at Cornell University 
April 17-18, 2020 at SUNY Binghamton

For additional information see the conference website: http://web.math.rochester.edu/people/faculty/cmlr/Finger-Lakes/.
 
The conference is aimed at professors, graduate students, and advanced undergraduates.  Its purpose is to facilitate communication between the probabilists near the Finger Lakes in Upstate New York, as well as to introduce graduate students and advanced undergraduates to the latest developments.  Probability is a rapidly developing area with many applications, and it is hard to be aware of all developments in the field. In past years professors and graduate students from more distant locations  such as Toronto, Boston, and New York City have also attended.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Today, probability is a flourishing field with applications across most 
areas of science and engineering.  As our scientific knowledge becomes more 
and more precise, the study of random noise becomes critical.  Although 
random events are unpredictable, there are strong regularities in the 
long-run behavior of large numbers of random events.  Such regularities can 
play a crucial role in the analysis of important scientific and 
technological questions.  

There is a strong tradition of regional probability conferences to bring 
young researchers up to date in the subject, and to allow communication 
between researchers of all ages.  The first such conference was the Midwest 
Probability Colloquium, which has been running steadily for 44 years.  

The Finger Lakes Probability Seminar follows in this tradition, building on 
the strength of universities in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York.  
These include Cornell University, University of Rochester, Syracuse University, 
and Binghamton University.  The conference lasts for two days, and includes 
three or four main talks, and many short contributed talks.  

In the four year that the seminar was held it consistently drew around 30 participants 
not only from the four hosting institutions, but also from many other nearby colleges and
universities. Overall there were a total of 12 prominent invited speakers who gave series of
lectures on their research. In addition, 32 graduate students, postdocts, and other young 
researchers gave contributed talk in the seminar, gaining valuable experience in
disseminating their work.

We find that such face-to-face communication can be a vital supplement to 
more formal activity such as publication.  These days most papers are 
written jointly, and conferences such as the Finger Lakes Probability 
Seminar can play a vital role in fostering such relationships.



Last Modified: 07/17/2023
Modified by: Sevak Mkrtchyan
